segment.source: Resources you'll need
segment.target: Resources you'll need

segment.source: Rendering a depth map for shadow volumes requires the following Direct3D device-dependent resources:
segment.target: Rendering a depth map for shadow volumes requires the following Direct3D device-dependent resources:

segment.source: A resource (buffer) for the depth map
segment.target: A resource (buffer) for the depth map

segment.source: A depth stencil view and shader resource view for the resource
segment.target: A depth stencil view and shader resource view for the resource

segment.source: A comparison sampler state object
segment.target: A comparison sampler state object

segment.source: Constant buffers for light POV matrices
segment.target: Constant buffers for light POV matrices

segment.source: A viewport for rendering the shadow map (typically a square viewport)
segment.target: A viewport for rendering the shadow map (typically a square viewport)

segment.source: A rendering state object to enable front face culling
segment.target: A rendering state object to enable front face culling

segment.source: You will also need a rendering state object to switch back to back face culling, if you don't already use one.
segment.target: You will also need a rendering state object to switch back to back face culling, if you don't already use one.

segment.source: Note that creation of these resources needs to be included in a device-dependent resource creation routine, that way your renderer can recreate them if (for example) a new device driver is installed, or the user moves your app to a monitor attached to a different graphics adapter.
segment.target: Note that creation of these resources needs to be included in a device-dependent resource creation routine, that way your renderer can recreate them if (for example) a new device driver is installed, or the user moves your app to a monitor attached to a different graphics adapter.

segment.source: Check feature support
segment.target: Check feature support

segment.source: Before creating the depth map, call the CheckFeatureSupport method on the Direct3D device, request D3D11\_FEATURE\_D3D9\_SHADOW\_SUPPORT, and provide a D3D11\_FEATURE\_DATA\_D3D9\_SHADOW\_SUPPORT structure.
segment.target: Before creating the depth map, call the CheckFeatureSupport method on the Direct3D device, request D3D11\_FEATURE\_D3D9\_SHADOW\_SUPPORT, and provide a D3D11\_FEATURE\_DATA\_D3D9\_SHADOW\_SUPPORT structure.

segment.source: If this feature is not supported, do not try to load shaders compiled for shader model 4 level 9\_x that call sample comparison functions.
segment.target: If this feature is not supported, do not try to load shaders compiled for shader model 4 level 9\_x that call sample comparison functions.

segment.source: In many cases, lack of support for this feature means that the GPU is a legacy device with a driver that isn't updated to support at least WDDM 1.2.
segment.target: In many cases, lack of support for this feature means that the GPU is a legacy device with a driver that isn't updated to support at least WDDM 1.2.

segment.source: If the device supports at least feature level 10\_0 then you can load a sample comparison shader compiled for shader model 4\_0 instead.
segment.target: If the device supports at least feature level 10\_0 then you can load a sample comparison shader compiled for shader model 4\_0 instead.

segment.source: Create depth buffer
segment.target: Create depth buffer

segment.source: First, try creating the depth map with a higher-precision depth format.
segment.target: First, try creating the depth map with a higher-precision depth format.

segment.source: Set up matching shader resource view properties first.
segment.target: Set up matching shader resource view properties first.

segment.source: If the resource creation fails, for example due to low device memory or a format that the hardware doesn't support, try a lower-precision format and change properties to match.
segment.target: If the resource creation fails, for example due to low device memory or a format that the hardware doesn't support, try a lower-precision format and change properties to match.

segment.source: This step is optional if you only need a low-precision depth format, for example when rendering on medium-resolution Direct3D feature level 9\_1 devices.
segment.target: This step is optional if you only need a low-precision depth format, for example when rendering on medium-resolution Direct3D feature level 9\_1 devices.

segment.source: Then create the resource views.
segment.target: Then create the resource views.

segment.source: Set the mip slice to zero on the depth stencil view and set mip levels to 1 on the shader resource view.
segment.target: Set the mip slice to zero on the depth stencil view and set mip levels to 1 on the shader resource view.

segment.source: Both have a texture dimension of TEXTURE2D, and both need to use a matching DXGI\_FORMAT.
segment.target: Both have a texture dimension of TEXTURE2D, and both need to use a matching DXGI\_FORMAT.

segment.source: Create comparison state
segment.target: Create comparison state

segment.source: Now create the comparison sampler state object.
segment.target: Now create the comparison sampler state object.

segment.source: Feature level 9\_1 only supports D3D11\_COMPARISON\_LESS\_EQUAL.
segment.target: Feature level 9\_1 only supports D3D11\_COMPARISON\_LESS\_EQUAL.

segment.source: Filtering choices are explained more in Supporting shadow maps on a range of hardware - or you can just pick point filtering for faster shadow maps.
segment.target: Filtering choices are explained more in Supporting shadow maps on a range of hardware - or you can just pick point filtering for faster shadow maps.

segment.source: Note that you can specify the D3D11\_TEXTURE\_ADDRESS\_BORDER address mode and it will work on feature level 9\_1 devices.
segment.target: Note that you can specify the D3D11\_TEXTURE\_ADDRESS\_BORDER address mode and it will work on feature level 9\_1 devices.

segment.source: This applies to pixel shaders that don't test whether the pixel is in the light's view frustum before doing the depth test.
segment.target: This applies to pixel shaders that don't test whether the pixel is in the light's view frustum before doing the depth test.

segment.source: By specifying 0 or 1 for each border, you can control whether pixels outside the light's view frustum pass or fail the depth test, and therefore whether they are lit or in shadow.
segment.target: By specifying 0 or 1 for each border, you can control whether pixels outside the light's view frustum pass or fail the depth test, and therefore whether they are lit or in shadow.

segment.source: On feature level 9\_1, the following required values must be set: MinLOD is set to zero, MaxLOD is set to D3D11\_FLOAT32\_MAX, and MaxAnisotropy is set to zero.
segment.target: On feature level 9\_1, the following required values must be set: MinLOD is set to zero, MaxLOD is set to D3D11\_FLOAT32\_MAX, and MaxAnisotropy is set to zero.

segment.source: Create render states
segment.target: Create render states

segment.source: Now create a render state you can use to enable front face culling.
segment.target: Now create a render state you can use to enable front face culling.

segment.source: Note that feature level 9\_1 devices require DepthClipEnable set to true.
segment.target: Note that feature level 9\_1 devices require DepthClipEnable set to true.

segment.source: Create a render state you can use to enable back face culling.
segment.target: Create a render state you can use to enable back face culling.

segment.source: If your rendering code already turns on back face culling, then you can skip this step.
segment.target: If your rendering code already turns on back face culling, then you can skip this step.

segment.source: Create constant buffers
segment.target: Create constant buffers

segment.source: Don't forget to create a constant buffer for rendering from the light's point of view.
segment.target: Don't forget to create a constant buffer for rendering from the light's point of view.

segment.source: You can also use this constant buffer to specify the light position to the shader.
segment.target: You can also use this constant buffer to specify the light position to the shader.

segment.source: Use a perspective matrix for point lights, and use an orthogonal matrix for directional lights (such as sunlight).
segment.target: Use a perspective matrix for point lights, and use an orthogonal matrix for directional lights (such as sunlight).

segment.source: Fill the constant buffer data.
segment.target: Fill the constant buffer data.

segment.source: Update the constant buffers once during initialization, and again if the light values have changed since the previous frame.
segment.target: Update the constant buffers once during initialization, and again if the light values have changed since the previous frame.

segment.source: Create a viewport
segment.target: Create a viewport

segment.source: You need a separate viewport to render to the shadow map.
segment.target: You need a separate viewport to render to the shadow map.

segment.source: The viewport isn't a device-based resource; you're free to create it elsewhere in your code.
segment.target: The viewport isn't a device-based resource; you're free to create it elsewhere in your code.

segment.source: Creating the viewport along with the shadow map can help make it more convenient to keep the dimension of the viewport congruent with the shadow map dimension.
segment.target: Creating the viewport along with the shadow map can help make it more convenient to keep the dimension of the viewport congruent with the shadow map dimension.
